abstract.p: Judith M Barzilay letter disputes Judge Abner Mikva's August 28 Op-Ed article, which opposes participation of judges in legal seminars, sponsored at resorts by corporations and foundations having interest in federal litigation on environmental topics

block.p: Re ''The Wooing of Our Judges,'' by Abner Mikva (Op-Ed, Aug. 28):

All judges are exposed on a daily basis to information that may be pertinent to the cases under adjudication. While I do not condone the failure of judges to report attendance at corporate-financed legal seminars, I do think it would be unwise to prevent them from participating.
Re ''The Wooing of Our Judges,'' by Abner Mikva (Op-Ed, Aug. 28):

All judges are exposed on a daily basis to information that may be pertinent to the cases under adjudication. While I do not condone the failure of judges to report attendance at corporate-financed legal seminars, I do think it would be unwise to prevent them from participating.

After all, the job we are appointed to do is to read the most highly charged advocacy for a particular position -- the briefs submitted by counsel for the parties before us -- and then choose among the competing interests consistent with our interpretation of the law. This skill is one that should be applicable to all the information we process, including that coming in the form of sponsored seminars.
JUDITH M. BARZILAY New York, Aug. 28, 2000
The writer is a judge in the United States Court of International Trade.
